title: How to Cook Brussels Sprouts in a Pan

steps.headline: Clean 20-24 Brussels sprouts in cold water to remove dirt.
steps.description: Pull off some of the outer layers of leaves, because these are the generally the dirtiest part. Cut them in half lengthwise. Use a small knife to remove the stem and any blemished leaves. After peeling the sprouts, you still need to rinse the inner layers under cold water just to get rid of any leftover dirt and bacteria. A paring knife is a good tool for cutting the stem off Brussels sprouts, because it’s small and gives you control in how you maneuver the Brussels sprouts’ round bottoms.

steps.headline: Add 1 tablespoon (15 mL) of olive oil to the skillet.
steps.description: Heat the oil over medium heat. Cut the sprouts in half and place them flat side down in a pan of olive oil. Cook on one side for 5 minutes, and then flip them and cook for 5 minutes on the other side. The flat side should look deep gold and black. Don’t move the sprouts around while they’re being seared. This isn’t sautéing. When searing, Brussels sprouts should cook on the flat side for an evenly distributed brown and black look. The flavor is also in the coloring, and you want them all to have a nice even flavor throughout.

steps.headline: Stir in butter, shallots, garlic, lemon zest and white wine.
steps.description: Lemon zest should be from ½ a lemon. You should use one finely chopped garlic clove and one small finely chopped shallot. These only need to be stirred for a few moments. Adding ⁄3 cup (79 mL) of dry white wine allows all the flavors in the pan to concentrate and blend together. White wine also deglazes the pan. Because white wine is also sweet, it helps to reduce Brussels sprouts natural bitterness. Sour flavors, such as lemon zest, decrease the bitterness that turns a lot of people away from Brussels sprouts.

steps.headline: Complete the process by adding Kosher salt and pepper to taste.
steps.description: You should also add lemon wedges to the side of the dish to balance the seared flavor with some citrus. Squeeze the lemon juice from the wedges onto the Brussels sprouts. Salting is another wonderful way to reduce the bitter flavor in Brussels sprouts. It’s the same reason people might add salt to a bad cup of coffee. For a complete meal, serve a fried egg on top of the sprouts, or pair them as a side dish with any kind of meat such as fish, pork, chicken and steak.

steps.headline: Store leftovers in airtight packaging in the fridge.
steps.description: Sealed storage containers such as Tupperware are also acceptable and can help prevent bacteria growth, retain moisture, and prevent leftovers from absorbing other odors in the fridge. Leftovers should be refrigerated or frozen within 2 hours of cooking the food. Leftovers can be stored in the refrigerator for 3 to 4 days or frozen for 3 to 4 months. However, frozen leftovers tend to lose moisture and flavor when stored longer than 4 months.

methods.name: Caramelizing Brussels Sprouts in a Cast-Iron Pan

steps.headline: Trim and cut Brussels sprouts in half lengthwise.
steps.description: Use 1 pound (0.45 kg) of Brussels sprouts for this method. Trim off blemished and wilting outer leaves until greener and fresher leaves are exposed. Cutting them in half allows for them to cook thoroughly in the pan since their surface area makes more contact with the pan. Rinse the under-layers to get rid of any dirt and bacteria.

steps.headline: Preheat the pan over low heat while you’re preparing the ingredients.
steps.description: You can slowly increase the heat to medium low, then medium and then high. Preheating a cast-iron pan slowly gives you more control over the temperature.

steps.headline: Put the cast-iron skillet over medium-high heat for 5 minutes.
steps.description: Add 3 tablespoons (44 mL) of canola oil to the pan when it’s hot enough to be sizzling. You can test the pan’s temperature by flicking tap water over it, and if the water gives a good sizzle, that means the pan is hot enough. For this, you need a 12 in (30 cm) cast-iron pan. Alternatively, make 2 smaller batches if you don’t have a pan of that size. Never put Brussels sprouts, or any food, onto a cold cast-iron pan before it’s completely hot on the bottom, because the food will stick to it.

steps.headline: Cook Brussels sprouts without stirring for 4 minutes, or until browned.
steps.description: After 4 minutes, stir in kosher salt, and cook for 2 more minutes. Brussels sprouts should be cooked cut side down, so the heat penetrates them thoroughly.

steps.headline: Add the remaining ingredients and glaze to the pan.
steps.description: Stir 1 tablespoon (15 mL) of honey and hot water together to make glaze. Honey will add sweetness to your Brussels sprouts and cut their natural bitterness. Don’t add the glaze until you put the garlic, soy sauce, and dried red pepper in to the pan. Add minced garlic, soy sauce, dried crushed red pepper and the honey mixture to the sprouts. Stir in ⁄2 cup (120 mL) of mint leaves for extra flavor and serve the Brussels sprouts right away.

methods.name: Roasting Brussels sprouts in a Cast-Iron Pan

steps.headline: Clean and trim 1 pound (0.45 kg) of Brussels sprouts.
steps.description: Cut them in half lengthwise. This is how you eliminate insecticides and blemished leaves. Rinse them in a colander and then trim off their stems. Start peeling the outer leaves until you see greener, fresher leaves underneath. You may want to use a paring knife to cut a small X in the bottom of each one to ensure they cook more evenly.

steps.headline: Pre-heat the oven to 350 °F (177 °C).
steps.description: Let it preheat while you arrange the Brussels sprouts in the pan. After cutting the Brussels sprouts, toss them into a bowl with 1 teaspoon (4.9 mL) of minced garlic, 1 teaspoon (4.9 mL) of lemon juice, and 2 tablespoons (30 mL) of olive oil. The sprouts should be well coated with olive oil.

steps.headline: Put the Brussels sprouts in the cast-iron pan.
steps.description: Cast-iron pans retain heat better than regular roasting pans, so the heat is more even throughout the process of cooking. Lay the Brussels sprouts out in one layer with space between them, so they cook evenly and don’t stick to each other. Add at least ⁄2 teaspoon (2.5 mL) of salt and some black pepper before putting the pan in the oven to roast.

steps.headline: Roast the Brussels sprouts in the oven at 350 °F (177 °C).
steps.description: When you put the pan in the oven, put it on the top rack for 30 minutes, and stir the sprouts halfway through the cooking time. Increase or decrease the cooking time depending on the size of the Brussels sprouts and how strong your oven is. You should see the sprouts browning with some of the leaves crunchy and the insides cooked through. They shouldn’t be burnt. If they look like they’re browning too much, move them to the lower rack or adjust the heat to a lower temperature. If you notice that your Brussels sprouts are not brown enough after 30 minutes, put them in the broiler for 5 minutes, or increase the oven’s heat to 500 °F (260 °C) for 5 minutes.

steps.headline: Remove them from the oven and serve.
steps.description: You can sprinkle them with Parmesan cheese to cover their natural bitterness and add some saltiness to their flavor. Adding anything fatty and salty to Brussels sprouts will make them more palatable to people who are reluctant to eat them.

steps.headline: Store leftovers in airtight packaging in the fridge.
steps.description: Sealed storage containers such as Tupperware are also acceptable and can help prevent bacteria growth, retain moisture, and prevent leftovers from absorbing other odors in the fridge. Leftovers should be refrigerated or frozen within 2 hours of cooking the food. Leftovers can be stored in the refrigerator for 3 to 4 days or frozen for 3 to 4 months. However, frozen leftovers tend to lose moisture and flavor when stored longer than 4 months.
